captions.text: Maps that will make you realize
you know nothing about the Earth.

This is the world, according
to the Mercator map projection.
You see this map everywhere,
but did you know that it's a total lie?!
Because the Earth is a sphere,

there is no way to show it
perfectly on a flat map.
So, all maps are distorted.
Here is how countries actually compare.
You might think North America
looking like nothing compared to Russia,
but in reality Russia is only about
2.1 times larger than the continental US.
Canada here is all wrong.
First of all, it's way too big.

Canada is actually only about
1.2 times the size of the US.
Secondly, Canada is shaped more like this.
The United States vs Canada.
What?
The UK actually looks like this

and Madagascar actually
looks more like this.
And here's what they look like
compared to the United States.

Greenland and Africa look
roughly the same size,
but in reality this is how they compare.
Africa is almost 14 times larger.

In fact, Africa is larger
than a lot of places.

You know that huge sheet of
ice at the bottom of the map?

Well, that is Antarctica
and it looks like this.

And compared to Africa,
it looks like this.
Never trust a map.
For even more wonderful things,
subscribe to BuzzFeed Blue.
BuzzFeed Blue.

title: Maps That Prove You Don't Really Know Earth

comments.text:
I can't believe that this is a video about how maps are incorrect and the 
video still wrongfully states that in most of todays maps the uk includes 
the republic of Ireland. That's totally false, any map from 1933 onward 
shows the republic separate from the uk. That's a simple fact, this video 
is wrongfully quoting todays maps for extra popularity. Total bullshit. Its 
getting the basic term "British isles" which includes the Republic mixed up 
with "United kingdom" which only includes northern Ireland.﻿

comments.text:
It's important to note that the Mercator projection was created by someone 
from what is now Germany; he wanted to make his homeland appear larger and 
more central to the globe. In reality, modern Germany is actually smaller 
than the US state of Montana and much further north...﻿

comments.author: Ellie Cruddace

comments.text:
The distortions pointed out in this video is the main reason this 
projection (the Mercator projection) is not considered a good fit for world 
maps anymore. The National Geographic uses a projection called 
"Winkel tripel" in their world maps nowadays, which has far less distortion 
than the Mercator projection featured in this video.﻿
